Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Convergence of Space Geodesy in Plate Boundary Research and Geoscience Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates the kinematics and mechanics of oblique convergence and strain partitioning and the geodynamic affects of ridge collision on upper plate deformation subduction zones to gain a better understanding of the formation of fore-arc terranes. This study integrates new and existing GPS data, seismic data (earthquake locations and centroid moment tensor solutions), and geologic observations with numerical models to: 1) estimate the magnitude and spatial variability of coupling on interplate thrust and fore-arc strike-slip faults; 2) determine the rate of fore arc motion; and 3) conduct an analysis of the forces associated with strain partitioning and ridge collision. The study focuses on two convergent margins, southern Central America (Cocos-Nazca-Caribbean plates: Panama) and northern South America (Nazca-South America plates: Ecuador). In southern Central America, Cocos plate convergence is orthogonal and the Cocos Ridge collides with the margin. There is no well-developed margin parallel fore-arc strike-slip fault here and it has been suggested that fore-arc motion to the northwest and southeast is driven by ridge collision. In northern South America, Nazca plate convergence is oblique and the Carnegie Ridge collides with the margin. Margin parallel fore-arc strike-slip faults accommodate northeast motion of the North Andean block. GPS networks will be established in Panama and Ecuador to better constrain the kinematics of surface deformation caused by the interaction of the Cocos and Nazca plates with the Central American isthmus (Caribbean plate) and South American plate. The educational component of this CAREER award : 1) enhances quantitative literacy in the geosciences through the development of six plate tectonics spreadsheet modules whose effectiveness will be assessed; 2) provides international research and education experiences for undergraduate students through the UNAVCO Research Experience in Solid Earth Science for Students and the Penn State University Center for Advanced Undergraduate Studies Experience programs; and 3) provides international research and education experiences for graduate students; 4) forms the basis for new courses on plate boundaries.

Subduction zone plate boundaries release the greatest amount of elastic energy producing great earthquakes and devastating tsunamis. The interaction of plates at subduction zones can be complex where convergence between plates is not orthogonal to the plate margin and where submarine ridges collide. In these cases, motion in the overriding plate can be partitioned between megathrust and strike-slip motion. This study aims determine the forces that control this behavior in two examples in Panama and Ecuador through a combined use of GPS data, which will refine the motion vectors, and modeling to constrain the forces at play. Students will be engaged in the project through classroom activities using the data and through international research experiences. The results of this study will assist in understanding earthquake hazards in Central America.

This research project is supported by the Earth Sciences Division's Tectonics and Education & Human Resources Programs and the Office of International Science and Engineering Americas Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this NSF award were to investigate the kinematics and lithospheric geodynamics of oblique convergence and resulting strain partitioning, and ridge collision in Panama and Ecuador, by increasing the global coverage of Global Positioning System (GPS) stations through the installation of new semi-continuous (S) GPS and continuous (C) GPS networks, and to integrate research on the lithospheric geodynamics of convergent margins into graduate and undergraduate education. The first goal was addressed through exploration of the following questions: 1) What are the magnitudes and spatial variability of driving/resistive forces at convergent margins? 2) Can we separate the effects of interseismic elastic strain accumulation from those of rigid indenter tectonics? The second goal was addressed through: 1) international research and education experiences for undergraduate students through the UNAVCO RESESS program and Penn State Geosciences Pulse of the Earth lab? 2) graduate training in space geodesy (GPS), lithospheric geodynamics and education; and 3) development of hands-on laboratory exercises that reinforce quantitative learning in volcanology and geodesy spreadsheet modules.

This award led to the development of new collaborations in Panama, Colombia and Ecuador. These collaborations have aided in the development of the newest velocity field for the region through site installation, data collection, and data sharing. In 2011, we ran a GPS analysis and elastic modeling short course for our Colombia and Ecuador colleagues, and an in the field training for our Panamanian colleagues throughout the project. This led to one Ecuadorian participant coming to Penn State for a PhD (in progress). We also collaborated with the UNAVCO led COCONet project, through cGPS station citing, site installation and data sharing. The new stations installed for this project are useful to the COCONet and broader geodesy community, as our results are being used for the Global Strain Rate Map project, which is an important input for the Global Earthquake Model, and by the atmospheric/weather modeling community investigating how much water is in the troposphere in the region. All GPS data have been archived at UNAVCO.

We installed five (5) new cGPS stations in Panama, collected new data from existing episodic and sGPS stations in Panama and Cosa Rica, and combined these data with published velocities to produce the first comprehensive 3D velocity field for all of Central America and northwestern South America (Kobayahi et al., 2014). We used elastic block modeling to investigate the magnitude and spatial variability of interseismic coupling on major plate boundary faults and the relative motion (rates) across faults in Central America to answer the first question above. This work provided new understanding to the potential location and magnitude of future plate boundary earthquakes and also demonstrates the nature of upper plate deformation caused by subduction/collision of aseismic ridges (i.e., the Cocos Ridge). One of the key findings was that the Central America forearc migrates from central Costa Rica to Guatemala at rates of 11-14 mm/yr. Understanding the motion of the Central American forearc is important for improving our understanding of upper plate earthquake generation, and in assessing the interseismic and co- and post-seismic behavior of the Middle America megathrust fault (Geirsson et al., 2015).

Continued data collection, analysis and expansion of the velocity field, has allowed for more testing of the kinematics of the southwestern Caribbean, indicating that this region (Costa Rica, Panama and Colombia) is a broad zone of deformation with several small tectonic blocks separated by seismically active faults (Ruiz et al., in preparation). The deformation is driven by collision and indentation of the Cocos Ridge. Furthermore, modeling of a GPS-derived velocity field for northern South America, indicates that the North Andes block migrates to the north, but is bordered to by diffuse zones of deformation (Mora-Paez et al. submitted; Ruiz et al, in preparation).

Four graduate students have been trained in GPS geodesy under this award, including one MSc thesis and three PhD dissertation (in progress). These students were involved in various aspects of the project from cGPS site installation, to GPS data collection, analysis, and modeling, and mentoring undergraduates students. The PI mentored a Research Experiences in Solid Earth Science for Students (RESESS) student for two summers. The RESESS student worked with the PI in the field in Panama and conducted a modeling study of stress triggering of the 1707 Mt. Fuji eruption by the 1707 M>8.7 Hoei earthquake (Chesley et al., 2012). The data analysis and modeling from the project were integrated into a two-semester undergraduate course focusing on magma-tectonic interactions through our Pulse of the Earth lab.
